text.p: Following are the top stories from selected Singapore newspapers. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Sexual offences committed against maids working here are a matter of public concern, Justice T.S. Sinnathuray said when he found a youth guilty of raping an Indonesian maid.
- Singapore's labour turnover has fallen gradually in recent years and is no longer as far ahead of South Korea, Taiwan and Japan, the Labour Ministry said.
- Two British soldiers here on a military exercise were charged of robbing a taxi driver of Singapore $43 earlier this month.
- Singapore-listed shipping firm Osprey Maritime is acquiring Monaco-based Gotaas-Larsen Shipping Corporation for US$750 million and proposed a host of fund raising issues to finance the mega deal
- Singapore's second cellular operator M1 and its partners have joined forces again to bid for a basic telecommunications licence.
- The U.S. Federal Trade Commission says it has no anti-trust concerns about Neptune Orient Lines' plans to acquire APL Ltd.
- Hundreds of Indonesian workers at Busang mine have taken a Bre-X minerals company manager and a surveyor hostage, news reports said.
- The Jardine group to buy Inchcape plc's wine and spirits division, which will then be merged with its own Jardine Wines & Spirits to form second largest wine distributor in Singapore.

- Property developer Straits Trading has had to delay the launch of its now-completed Farrer Road condo project, Gallop Gables, because of soft market sentiment in the wake of last May's anti-speculation measures.
- Mainboard-listed DBS Land plans to launch three residential projects in Hong Kong this year.

- Keppel Corporation and Singapore Press Holdings have roped in Cable & Wireless plc, the U.K.'s second-largest telecommunications company, and Hongkong Telecom to bid for a fixed-wire telecom licence in Singapore.
